title: CI: unit tests should run against a full install, not an editable install

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behaviour

labels.name: ci
labels.description: Relating to Continuous Integration / GitHub Actions

body:
### Issue Description

The CI unit tests do not test the built library; they use a local "editable" install. This means that problems with the build/packaging are likely to be missed. This is concerning, as it could lead us to unknowingly publish a broken wheel.

Issue https://github.com/slundberg/shap/issues/3012 is an example of this: the tests pass on CI, but fail when running with cibuildwheel. This change aims to prevent that happening in future.

Another recent example is #3021 - a packaging error was inadvertently introduced in a previous PR, which broke the wheels and was not caught on CI.

Related #2979

### Ensuring the correct library is picked up

The fix is not as simple as removing the `--editable` flag from `pip install`, as the wrong library can be imported on sys.path. The library is installed to `/lib/python3.11/site-packages`, but when shap is imported the library incorrectly imported from the current working directory `/home/runner/work/shap/shap/shap/__init__.py`. More info in this recent [CI run](https://github.com/slundberg/shap/actions/runs/5337284077/jobs/9673122016?pr=3017#step:6:68) .

A quick fix is to replace `python -m pytest` with `pytest`, as that avoids adding the current working directory to sys.path. However, this is not particularly robust.

A full fix would be migrating to a `src/` layout. From the [pytest docs](https://docs.pytest.org/en/7.2.x/explanation/goodpractices.html#tests-outside-application-code):

> Generally, but especially if you use the default import mode prepend, it is **strongly suggested** to use a src layout. Here, your application root package resides in a sub-directory of your root, i.e. src/mypkg/ instead of mypkg.
> 
> This layout prevents a lot of common pitfalls and has many benefits, which are better explained in this excellent [blog post](https://blog.ionelmc.ro/2014/05/25/python-packaging/#the-structure%3E) by Ionel Cristian Mărieș.
